stories.text:
I live in the country and have one yard light. It's on a timer and goes until 2 or 3 a.m. It used to be mercury discharge but years ago was switched to HP sodium (70 watt) which is far more efficient and also gives a very pleasant light for nighttime illumination. Sure, it has low CRI factor but it provides the light I need to accomplish any chores that need doing at night, like feeding my outdoor wood furnace, while not making the area seem like it's daytime. The old mercury light did not provide any more illumination but used 150 watts of electricity. More importantly the light was way too harsh and daylight-like, just inappropriate for a night light. I might even switch to a 50-watt HPS bulb as the light is that efficient. The bulbs last for many years and are not expensive.

Driving on streets that are lighted with full spectrum LED lamps are similarly harsh and, in my opinion, unsettling. I guess it depends on what night lighting is for, to see what needs to be seen or see those things in daylight-quality illumination, with all its advantages and faults.

I just hope people consider all the angles before rushing into LED street lighting.
stories.title: Don't give up your High Pressure Sodium Lamps
